definition[1]: (Personal Equity Plan) a type of savings plan introduced by the British government in the 1980s, which allows people to buy small amounts of shares in British companies without having to pay tax on the profits they make by doing this. PEPs were introduced to encourage ordinary people to buy shares. A new savings plan called the ‘ ISA’ replaced PEPs in 1999.
definition[2]: Personal Equity Plan; an investment plan introduced by the British government in 1987 to encourage ordinary people to own shares and invest in industry by allowing them to not pay any tax on the money made. In April 1999 PEPs were replaced by ISAs
